Award.AwardTitle: Topology and geometry of Cayley graphs for groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of the proposed research is to investigate the interplay between topological/geometric properties of groups and algorithms for solving the word, conjugacy, and related problems. Major directions for this research include: (1) Applications of autostackable structures to 3-manifold groups, Thompson's group F, and metabelian groups; these structures are characterized using a combination of topological and formal language theory properties of the Cayley graph, and provide algorithms for solving the word problem and for building Dehn diagrams for the group. (2) A study of the asymptotic growth of conjugacy classes and of geodesic words and elements (up to conjugacy) of groups. (3) Improving understanding of filling invariants, by studying refinements of the isodiametric (i.e. intrinsic diameter) inequality and its extrinsic analog. (4) Applications of group invariants to problems in knot theory; local moves, in combination with the standard Reidemeister operations, will be studied to determine when these local moves are (or are not) unknotting or unlinking operations.

The proposed work is centered around mathematical problems at the interface between group theory, geometry, and computer science. Group theory is the mathematical study of symmetries of objects; this research area has its beginnings in the study of crystal structures in chemistry, but now has wide applications across many disparate areas of mathematics and the sciences. Knot theory also has seen wide application in recent years, and in particular the study of unknotting via local moves is used to model enzyme actions on DNA molecules. The methods proposed make essential use of tools from one or more of these fields to shed light on important problems in another field. In particular geometric methods are used in the pursuit of computationally effective and efficient algorithms for groups, and algorithmic methods are used to determine geometric properties of groups, including applications to knot theory. This project includes mentoring of undergraduate and graduate students in mathematics research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research in this project centered on applications of computational and geometric methods in group theory and knot theory. Group theory is the mathematical study of symmetries of objects; this research area has wide applications across many areas of mathematics and the sciences.  

The group theory results of the project include development of the foundations of two new topics in geometric group theory. The first topic is a study of a new type of algorithm, called autostackability, that solves a fundamental computational question for a group, called the word problem, using finite state automata (computers with a finite amount of memory). In work with M. Brittenham, D. Holt, A. Johnson, and C. Martinez-Perez, we built the general theory of autostackability.  An original goal in the development of the widely applied theory of automatic groups was to solve the word problem for closed 3-manifold groups using finite state automata, but 3-manifolds with Nil or Sol pieces are not automatic. In one of our results on this topic, together with M. Brittenham and T. Susse we show that all closed (or more generally, compact with incompressible toral boundary) 3-manifold groups are autostackable, achieving that original goal. The second topic is a study of growth of groups with respect to conjugacy. Computation of growth of conjugacy classes in finitely generated groups is often difficult, because the growth series is rarely rational. In one of our results in this area, working with L. Ciobanu, D. Holt, and S. Rees we show that the growth of the set of minimal length elements in conjugacy classes, and the growth of conjugacy geodesics, are rational, and moreover there is a practical procedure for computing these rational functions using language theoretic tools, for many important classes of groups in geometric group theory. These results open up new, and more accessible, avenues for measuring growth.

Knot theory, the study of knotted loops in 3-dimensional space, is also a research area that has seen wide application across the sciences (biology, chemistry, and physics in particular) in recent years.  In another part of the project, large scale computation was applied by M. Brittenham and the PI to settle a twenty year old conjecture in knot theory, the Bernhard-Jablan conjecture.  The result shows that in order to compute an important knot invariant known as the unknotting number of a knot, it is insufficient in general to use only minimal knot diagrams at each step of the computation.

The research in the various parts of this project was done in collaboration with many researchers, and included the involvement, and mentoring, of ten graduate students, an undergraduate student, and a postdoctoral scholar at UNL. Four of these students completed their doctoral dissertations and degrees under the supervision of the PI during this grant.  The PI gave many lectures on the research results both nationally and internationally. The PI also pursued activities to improve the recruitment and retention of women in mathematics, and to improve professional development for graduate students going into nonacademic careers.
